Legal_Issue: Did the Citizenship Judge correctly apply the residency requirement under paragraph 5(1)(c) of the Citizenship Act?
Application_Facts: Applicant was physically present for 173 days and absent for 1,287 days
Court_Ruling: Appeal dismissed; applicant remains ineligible for citizenship
Defendant_Behavior: Failed to meet minimum physical presence requirement
Grounds_for_Claim: Alleged incorrect application of residency requirement by Citizenship Judge
Legal_Standard: Physical presence in Canada for 1,095 days
Assessment_Factor: Duration of physical presence in Canada
Procedural_Issue: Appeal filed under subsection 14(5) of the Citizenship Act
Evidence_Used: Record of entry and exit dates, applicant's travel history
Application_Basis: Re Pourghasemi test for physical presence
Evidence_Assessed: Days of physical presence in Canada
Governing_Rule: Re Pourghasemi – emphasis on physical presence
Evidentiary_Deficiency: Insufficient proof of required residency duration
Harm_Assessment: No harm from legal error; decision based on statutory compliance
Cause_Description: Applicant's failure to meet the residency requirement due to insufficient physical presence in Canada
Evidence_Handling: Reviewed official records of entry and exit
Residency_Compliance: Not met – only 173 days of physical presence
Evidence_Assessment: Accurate assessment of physical presence based on documented travel history
Decision_Rationale: Citizenship Judge correctly applied Re Pourghasemi and the law; adequate reasons provided
Decision_Making_Body: Citizenship Judge, reviewed by Federal Court
Legal_Standard_Applied: Re Pourghasemi test for physical presence
